importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Dutch government invoked the Goods Availability Act to take control of Nexperia on this date, citing serious administrative shortcomings and risks to European technological security.
An emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber concluded that there were valid reasons to doubt the management at Nexperia under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng.
China tightened export controls on critical rare-earth metals, citing national security, which intensified tensions between China and Western nations over semiconductor supply chains.
China's Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.

The US Bureau of Industry and Security extended export control restrictions to entities 50%+ owned by those on the US Entity List, including Wingtech, which raised concerns about Nexperia’s ownership and operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the escalation of geopolitical tensions surrounding semiconductor technology, culminating in the Dutch government's intervention in Nexperia due to perceived security threats.

keyTakeAways: The Dutch government took effective control of Nexperia, a global semiconductor manufacturer, under the Goods Availability Act due to concerns over managerial failures and risks to European technological security.
Nexperia, which was acquired by Chinese group Wingtech Technology in 2018, is central to Europe’s semiconductor supply chain and critical for AI and electric vehicle technologies.

The intervention followed an emergency hearing and was triggered by the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng, who is linked to Wingtech, and concerns about the company’s operations and product availability in Europe.
The Dutch government blocked key decisions at Nexperia for one year, including asset relocations, executive firings, or major strategic changes, to protect critical technological capabilities.

The move comes amid broader Western efforts to restrict China’s access to semiconductor technology, including US export controls and China’s own export restrictions on rare-earth metals and components.
Wingtech has criticized the Dutch intervention as politically motivated and based on geopolitical bias rather than factual risk, and shares have dropped significantly on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

China has condemned the intervention as an overreach of national security concepts and a politicization of commercial matters, while the EU is coordinating with the Netherlands to safeguard European tech capabilities.
Nexperia continues daily operations, with Stegan Tilger named interim CEO, and has committed to engaging with Chinese authorities to resolve export restrictions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch government has taken effective control of the semiconductor company Nexperia, a key European player in AI and electric vehicle technologies, due to concerns over managerial shortcomings under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng and the ownership by Chinese group Wingtech. This intervention, carried out under the highly exceptional Goods Availability Act on September 30, 2025, is framed as a necessary measure to safeguard critical technological capabilities and ensure product availability in Europe. The move follows a series of escalating geopolitical tensions, including US export controls on semiconductor tools and China’s tighter restrictions on rare-earth metal exports, which have heightened fears of supply chain disruptions. While Nexperia continues operations with interim CEO Stegan Tilger, the Dutch government has blocked key decisions for one year and prevented asset relocations or executive changes. Wingtech has criticized the intervention as politically motivated, and China has condemned it as a violation of market principles. The European Union is now coordinating with the Netherlands to protect Europe’s technological sovereignty in this high-stakes technological race.
title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?
